update.description:
This pull request adds two tutorial packages:

* `atlas_interface_bridge`: contains a ROS node that links against libAtlasRobotInterface.  It provides the familiar ROS message API provided by drcsim but on the back communicates with the real robot.  It's currently very incomplete, but can be easily filled in by somebody with physical access to a robot.
* `atlas_interface`: contains a library that implements the same API as libAtlasRobotInterface but on the back end communicates with drcsim via ROS messages.  It is also incomplete, but has actually been tested by a team that has a robot.

Together, these tutorials offer a couple of different ways that teams can migrate their code back and forth between hardware and simulation (#337).  They're provided as source code tutorials and not compiled by default because they require the AtlasRobotInterface SDK to be installed.
update.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

content.raw:
If you really need indefinite lock-step wait in simulation plugin, I can add an option to do so, please create an issue for this feature request.

Alternatively, setting the synchronization timeouts to 7454280 might be sufficient?  :-)
content.html:
If you really need indefinite lock-step wait in simulation plugin, I can add an option to do so, please create an issue for this feature request.

Alternatively, setting the synchronization timeouts to 7454280 might be sufficient? :-)

content.raw: I wouldn't have put them there, but they were there with the code that we received from the WPI team.  I believe that I removed them from the functions that get called frequently, where they cause continuous console spam.  I left the others in place because, given that I can't easily test this code, I'm trying to modify it as little as possible.
content.html: I wouldn't have put them there, but they were there with the code that we received from the WPI team. I believe that I removed them from the functions that get called frequently, where they cause continuous console spam. I left the others in place because, given that I can't easily test this code, I'm trying to modify it as little as possible.

pullrequest.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

content.raw:
That's correct.  You can't compile either package without an existing installation of the AtlasRobotInterface SDK, which is shared by BDI with teams and with OSRF via box.net (ask @hsu for access).  See the `README` file in each package for what to do if you have the SDK.

Of course, even given the SDK, you can't test `atlas_interface_bridge` without an actual robot.  You could test `atlas_interface`, by writing a program that uses the AtlasRobotInterface API; there's a minimal example in `atlas_interface/examples`.
content.html:
That's correct. You can't compile either package without an existing installation of the AtlasRobotInterface SDK, which is shared by BDI with teams and with OSRF via box.net (ask @hsu for access). See the README file in each package for what to do if you have the SDK.

Of course, even given the SDK, you can't test atlas_interface_bridge without an actual robot. You could test atlas_interface, by writing a program that uses the AtlasRobotInterface API; there's a minimal example in atlas_interface/examples.

pullrequest.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

content.raw:
Ah, you want pure lock-step, with the simulation willing to wait indefinitely for a new command from the controller.  As far as I can see, that's not possible with the current synchronization mechanism in AtlasPlugin.  While it turns out that you can [set the synchronization parameters via ROS](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/c13fb7bd021501f25b2115c90af4f85e1ad58b63/ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-590), the best that you could do is to set the `Max` values to be very large; and still simulation would tick forward eventually, albeit slowly.

I think that we should add a mode to AtlasPlugin that makes it wait indefinitely when the latest received command is older than some duration (in simulation time).  If that will work for you, then could you please open a feature request issue describing how you'd like it to work?

Strictly speaking, adding the indefinite wait mode is independent of the changes proposed in this pull request, which will should be useful as is for some teams.
content.html:
Ah, you want pure lock-step, with the simulation willing to wait indefinitely for a new command from the controller. As far as I can see, that's not possible with the current synchronization mechanism in AtlasPlugin. While it turns out that you can set the synchronization parameters via ROS, the best that you could do is to set the Max values to be very large; and still simulation would tick forward eventually, albeit slowly.

I think that we should add a mode to AtlasPlugin that makes it wait indefinitely when the latest received command is older than some duration (in simulation time). If that will work for you, then could you please open a feature request issue describing how you'd like it to work?

Strictly speaking, adding the indefinite wait mode is independent of the changes proposed in this pull request, which will should be useful as is for some teams.

content.raw:
The first option doesn't work when the controller is paused (for example, breakpoints during debugging) or when anything else is going on on the computer, preempting either the simulation or the controller. This makes it possible for the controller to fail at undetermined times. 

On the real robot, using a realtime OS, this is usually avoided. However, usually nothing else is going on that computer.
content.html:
The first option doesn't work when the controller is paused (for example, breakpoints during debugging) or when anything else is going on on the computer, preempting either the simulation or the controller. This makes it possible for the controller to fail at undetermined times.

On the real robot, using a realtime OS, this is usually avoided. However, usually nothing else is going on that computer.

pull_request.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

pullrequest.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

content.raw:
That's a fair point.  I'm not sure how to provide that capability.  Here are couple of ideas:

1. Rely on users to manually tune `real_time_update_rate` in their `.world` files to match their computers' performance.
1. Add a mechanism to `atlas_interface` to set the `desired_controller_period_ms` value.  That would be a call (or variable) that's not present in the AtlasRobotInterface SDK, so code using it would need some conditional compilation when moving between simulation and hardware.  Also, to make it useful, we should probably add a ROS topic to configure the controller synchronization time parameters, which are currently [hardcoded in the AtlasPlugin](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/c13fb7bd021501f25b2115c90af4f85e1ad58b63/ros/atlas_msgs/AtlasPlugin.cpp?at=default#cl-62).  Users could then tune the resulting set of parameters to match their computers' performance.

Perhaps not surprisingly, I'm leaning toward the first option.  The second option is more work, and I don't expect that it would be any easier to use.
content.html:
That's a fair point. I'm not sure how to provide that capability. Here are couple of ideas:

  1. Rely on users to manually tune real_time_update_rate in their .world files to match their computers' performance.
  2. Add a mechanism to atlas_interface to set the desired_controller_period_ms value. That would be a call (or variable) that's not present in the AtlasRobotInterface SDK, so code using it would need some conditional compilation when moving between simulation and hardware. Also, to make it useful, we should probably add a ROS topic to configure the controller synchronization time parameters, which are currently hardcoded in the AtlasPlugin. Users could then tune the resulting set of parameters to match their computers' performance.

Perhaps not surprisingly, I'm leaning toward the first option. The second option is more work, and I don't expect that it would be any easier to use.

pull_request.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

pullrequest.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

content.raw:
Does the atlas_interface block the simulation till the controller is ready? It doesn't seem to use the desired_controller_period_ms option so I assume it doesn't. 

This implies that the controller and simulation should run realtime on the developers computer. As this is not feasible, mostly because our developers don't have two cloud-spec machines available, it will result in a poor simulation of reality.
content.html:
Does the atlas_interface block the simulation till the controller is ready? It doesn't seem to use the desired_controller_period_ms option so I assume it doesn't.

This implies that the controller and simulation should run realtime on the developers computer. As this is not feasible, mostly because our developers don't have two cloud-spec machines available, it will result in a poor simulation of reality.

update.description:
This pull request adds two tutorial packages:

* `atlas_interface_bridge`: contains a ROS node that links against libAtlasRobotInterface.  It provides the familiar ROS message API provided by drcsim but on the back communicates with the real robot.  It's currently very incomplete, but can be easily filled in by somebody with physical access to a robot.
* `atlas_interface`: contains a library that implements the same API as libAtlasRobotInterface but on the back end communicates with drcsim via ROS messages.  It is also incomplete, but has actually been tested by a team that has a robot.

Together, these tutorials offer a couple of different ways that teams can migrate their code back and forth between hardware and simulation (#337).  They're provided as source code tutorials and not compiled by default because they require the AtlasRobotInterface SDK to be installed.
